discussion.content:
The commands needed in PowerShell script named UsersAndGroups.ps1 are :
Import-Csv C:\users\MyAlias\desktop\Groups.csv | ForEach-Object {New-SPOSiteGroup -Group $_.Group -PermissionLevels $_.PermissionLevels -Site $_.Site}
Import-Csv C:\users\MyAlias\desktop\Users.csv | where {Add-SPOUser -Group $_.Group â€“LoginName $_.LoginName -Site $_.Site}

Executing the PowerShell script:
Set-ExecutionPolicy Bypass
Enter 'Y' for the confirmation prompt
paste 'c:\users\MyAlias\desktop\UsersAndGroups.ps1'

Where MyAlias equals your user name

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
You manage multiple Microsoft SharePoint Online sites.
You have a CSV file named Groups.csv that contains the following data.

Site, Group, Permissions -
https://contoso1.sharepoint.com/sites/sitea, Project Leads, Full Control https://contoso1.sharepoint.com/sites/siteb, Auditors, View Only
You have a CSV file named Users.csv that contains the following data.

Group, LoginName, Site -
Project Leads, Lead1, https://contoso1.sharepoint.com/sites/sitea
Auditors, Auditor1, https://contoso1.sharepoint.com/sites/siteb
You need to create multiple SharePoint groups and add the users to the groups.
How should you complete the command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:

HOTSPOT -
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You need to ensure that users accessing files in Microsoft SharePoint Online from an unmanaged device can only view the files in a browser.
How should you complete the command? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
Hot Area:

discussion.content: -AllowEditing $false Prevents users from editing Office files in the browser and copying and pasting Office file contents out of the browser window.

Retrieves SharePoint Online company logs. This cmdlet is reserved for internal Microsoft (Or SharePoint Online administrator or Global Administrator to run the cmdlet.) use and does not retrieve service request information.

As per microsoft docs: This cmdlet is reserved for internal Microsoft use.
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/sharepoint-online/get-spotenantlogentry?view=sharepoint-ps
This cmdlet retrieves a subset of errors that happen due to external systems. It does not retrieve information on service request.

SharePoint administrators open several Microsoft support tickets.
You need to view the status of the support tickets.
Solution: You run the Get-SPOTenantLogEntry cmdlet.
Does this meet the goal?

discussion.content: because Excel add-in should be uploaded from O365 Admin ---settings-addins, not sharepoint add-ins

However, from https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/publish/publish-task-pane-and-content-add-ins-to-an-add-in-catalog the SharePoint add-in method still works, it's just not recommended. So I'm going with A.

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/publish/centralized-deployment - If you are deploying add-ins in an on-premises environment, use a SharePoint app catalog, if you're targeting the cloud, as we are in this case, Centralized Deployment is the recommended way for a Microsoft 365 admin to deploy Office Add-ins within an organization.

discussion.content:
This is not the correct solution. I think you need also need to tell the office client where the app catalog is. Here is an overview of all methods:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/office/dev/add-ins/publish/publish

Also the recommended way is to use centralized deployment in an online environment.
Add-ins deployed via the admin center are available to users in their Office applications right away, with no client configuration required.
This solution is correct because Get-SPOTenantLogEntry retrieves SharePoint Online Company logs
i think the solution is correct
